solution_line_template: The cost of the {num_employees_12} employees is {num_employees_12} employees * ${wage_12}/employee/hour = $<<{num_employees_12}*{wage_12}={cost_12_per_hour}>>{cost_12_per_hour} per hour.
The cost of the {num_employees_14} employees is {num_employees_14} employees * ${wage_14}/employee/hour = $<<{num_employees_14}*{wage_14}={cost_14_per_hour}>>{cost_14_per_hour} per hour.

The rest means {total_employees} employees - {num_employees_12} employees - {num_employees_14} employees = <<{total_employees}-{num_employees_12}-{num_employees_14}={num_employees_17}>>{num_employees_17} employees.
These {num_employees_17} employees' employment costs are at {num_employees_17} employees * ${wage_17}/employee/hour = $<<{num_employees_17}*{wage_17}={cost_17_per_hour}>>{cost_17_per_hour} per hour.
So in total all employees earn ${cost_12_per_hour}/hour + ${cost_14_per_hour}/hour + ${cost_17_per_hour}/hour = ${total_cost_per_hour}/hour.
During an {shift_hours}-hour shift, this cost would be at {shift_hours} hours * ${total_cost_per_hour}/hour = $<<{shift_hours}*{total_cost_per_hour}={total_shift_cost}>>{total_shift_cost}.
